The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: RIVALS AND ENEMIES
div.p: According to the "Evening Standard an: St. JarneH's Gazette," the meeting of the Kir, and the Kaiser offers a good opportunity for Great Britain and Germany to take stock their mutual relations. For years past thw has been a certain perceptible friction between the two countries. This, be it observed, ha-nothing to do with their Governments. The Foreign Offices of the Wilhelmstrasse and Downing-street have had no quarrel, no differ ences even, of any importance. A year ago when there were suggestions for a general settlement between England and Germany on the lines of the Anglo-French Convention, it was pointed out that there was really n«>-thing to settle. There were no outstanding questions at issue, like those, for instance, of Egypt and Siam and the Newfoundland fisheries. It was not a case for negotiations, or treaties, or diplomacy'at all. The Governments had no formal cognisance that there was any breach or any circumstance likely to lead to one.

The estrangement, so far as it has existed, hAs been one of popular sentiment, sedulously fomented by mistaken patriotism on both sides. Germans and Englishmen, good friends for centuries, and often close allies, gradually discovered, towards the end of the Bismarckiaa period, that they were not very fond of one another.

As Germany grew stronger, and more ambitious and aggressive, the feeling intensified. The Franco-German war had natu rally put the Teutonic peoples a little above themselves. Their self-satisfaction increased when they began to add the triumphs of peaz* to those of war. On the Continent of Europe they were the cocks of the walk. France' had been dethroned from her ancient pride of place; Russia was chaotic, and semi-barbarous ; Austria, Italy, Spain were in the second rank. But Germany discovered that she produced other things besides soldiers and professors. She could build great steamers, manufacture machinery, run cotton-mills and engine-sheds, and create an enormous export trade. Her ambitions turned to the wider world outside Europe, and, like the first Napoleon, she began to think of "Ships, Colonies, and Commerce," the mainstays of an Empire But here, wherever she looked, she saw herself brought up against the achievements of Britain. The ships, the colonies, the oversea trade, the great markets—they were ours already. Germany set herself diligently to wrest a share of these from us. We bent ourselves, somewhat slowly and contemptuously at first, to keeping what we had got. The situation led naturally to a certain bitterness. The Germans were irritated, because we had already obtained most of the things they wanted. We were annoyed because they were trying to take from us what we had come to regard almost as a monopoly. It was disagreeable to find ourselves faced everywhere by a new pushing concern, organised on the latest methods ; and on the other hand, it was mortifying for the new tiaders to realise that, with all their energy and enter prise, they were badly handicapped in the race with a competitor who had gained a century's start..

The commercial rivalry is a fact* with which we must make our account. It will not disappear or even diminish. Germany and England for a good many decades to come will be competitors in many lines of trade. But it does not follow that they need be enemies, if only because they are excellent customers for one another. So far as one can see there is no reason whatever why the warfare should not be waged by the merchants, the manufacturers, the shipowners, and shippers, without in the least involving the*8oldiers, the sailors, and the statesmen. It is true Germany has certain vague territorial ambitions, which may eventually bring her into conflict with us. But really that might be said of most other great countries—of France, Japan, Russia, the United States—and, indeed, wre have said it of nearly all in turn. It is barely ten years since it was almost a religion with patriotic Frenchmen and Englishmen to believe that a great wrar between the two countries was "inevitable." It is not much longer since we felt convinced that we should some time or other have to fight the United States for the possession of Canada ; and two generations of Britons have been brought up in the firm faith that between Russia and England no firm or lasting peace was possible. Now, we are tionate towards America, cordial towards Frtn* ce, and even disposed towards a reasonable friendship with Russia. These nations are still our rivals^industrially and politically; their aims are not, and never will be, completely attained without some interference with our own. Yet we have discovered that we need not hate them, and that they are far from hating us. And we may hope that we are on the eve of the same revelation with regard to Germany. Nations seem to be realising, as individuals and associations have done, that rivalry and enmity need not be necessarily conjoined. A trader may strive fiercely to undercut or outdo another man in business. But he does not go about uttering threats of personal violence, and may even be quite civil and friendly in his bearing towards his opponent when they meet in private life.

div.head: Egyptian Mining.
div.p: The Um Rus Mines sold the gold obtained in June for £1,654. (The mill ran 18 days of 24 hours.)

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Quarantine restrictions as against plague are now applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Trobizond.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records a fatal cave at Alexandria, and a fresh ease, a death, And a recovery at Suez.

div.head: San 8tefano Casino.
div.p: On Saturday next a ball will be given at the Casino for abonnes. As no special invitations are being issued admission will be by presenting season tickets.

div.head: Decrease in Cotton Worm.
div.p: A welcome proof of the decrease in the cotton worm is that twenty two moawius engaged in superintending the work of destruction of the pest have been dismissed.

div.head: A Sheikh Drowned.
div.p: Sheikh Abdul Aziz Osman, professor of Arabic in the Freres College, Cairo, who recently went to Al-Areesh to spend his summer leave, was drowned while bathing in the sea there a few days ago.

div.head: American Oil for Egypt.
div.p: The Caucasus riots have been a boon to the American petroleum industry. According to the "Progres," 110,000 cases of the Transatlantic oil are expected here from New York by the Italian S.S. Regina Elena.

div.head: San 8tefano Theatre.
div.p: There was a large audience yesterday evening for the "soiree noire" performance, which proved a great success. This evening's programme is as follows : 1 Le Gendarme estsans pitie; 2 Concert and Ballet ; 3 Le snuper d adieu.

div.head: Free Surgery.
div.p: The free medical surgery which has been opened recently at Alexandria by the native Masonic lodges hae already proved its utility. The first service performed was the saving of the life of an Arab who would have perished but for the prompt medioal attention he received.

div.head: The Ulema Board.
div.p: Six hundred religious students are now being examined by the Alexandria Ulema Board. In the oral examinations only 29 out of 900 examinees hitherto failed. The oral examinations will end on Thursday. The rest of the examination will end on the 6th September, when the prizes will be distributed.

div.head: Foum el Khalig.
div.p: The ceremony of "cutting the Khalig" takes place on Saturday next, when in observance of the event all the Government offices will be closed. The Ministry of War has given instructions regarding the salutes of 244 guns to be fired on the departure of the Akaba, on the arrival and departure of the Regent, and at other periods.

div.head: Forgery.
div.p: On Saturday last a native, pretending to be an ex-employd of the Government, betook himself to the Ministry of Finance, where he requested that an "estimara" to the value of L.E. 800 should be cashed for him. He declared that this was the total amount of his salary for 15 years, but the cashier observed that there was an error in estimating the stamp tax, and the forger was arrested. The man is said to be insane.

div.head: Duel between natives.
div.p: Mohamed Ibrahim and Tahir Mohamed, two "suffragis" in Cairo, belonging to the Ababdeh tribe, agreed on Sanday afternoon to settle their differences by an encounter on the Abbassieh hills, and half an hoar later they were at the appointed spot alone. The weapons used in the duel were nabouts. Mohamed Ibrahim was the first to draw blood, Tahir Mohamed receiving a tremendous blow on the head, which so enraged him that, taking a knife out of his belt, he stabbed bis adversary twioe in the leg. Mohamed Ibrahim, who was quicker in motion than the other, succeeded iD wrenching the weapon from Tahir Mohamed's hand and thrust it into his heart, killing him on the spot, and afterwards decamping. He was arrested shortly afterward?, however, and confessed his guilt. The injuries he sustained in the fight will require ten days' medical treatment The enquiry held shows that Mohamed and Tahir had been ou had terms with one of her in consequence of the latter being unwilling to allow the former to marry his niece

Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, 6 cretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: GERMANY AND EGYPT.
THE "DEUTSCHE REVUE" ARTICLES
GOVERNMENT ATTITUDE.
div.p: The Berlin Press have repudiated the articles published in the "Deutsche Revue' and say that they are ill advised and in no way official. The journal has no connection with the Government and does not even voice the opinions of an appreciable percentage of Germans. The Government at Berlin regards the question of Egypt as being perfectly settled, and the authorities are quite prepared to abide by the status quo.

As the culmination of a long series of attacks upon British policy in Egypt in the German Press, the last number of the "Deutsche Revue." which is reputed to speak with authority in matters of foreign policy, discussed the Egyptian "question" from the German point of view. The gist of the article is the proposal that Egypt should be treated as an object of common interest to England and Germany and that its future should be decided between the two Powers on the basis of compensating values. The course of reasoning by which this position is reached has been rendered familiar by the campaign which preceded the outbreak of the Morocco question last year.

The article premises the existence of an Anglo French "coalition" against Germany, with which she will have to reckon. The Anglo French Convention of 1904 is described as the logical sequel to Disraeli's conquete hypothecaire of the Suez Canal and as evidence of British determination to absorb Egypt before Germany has firmly established herself in Asia Minor. Of this intention Lord Cromer's proposals for ameliorating the judicial system and for facilitating the work of administration are regarded as affording the necessary proof. Lord Cromer's proposals are represented as a direct attack upon the Capitulations and as the first step towards the abolition of the exterritoriality of foreigners. With the abolition of these regulations the security of foreigners would be at an end, since the reconstituted Courts would be subject to British influence. The suggestion that a local board of control, international in its composition, should be substituted for diplomatic representation is treated with suspicion, notwithstanding Lord Cromer's very categorical assurances, upon the ground that the British community would be invested with a preponderating vote, upon the strength of superior interests. Lord Cromer's other proposals are examined in a similar spirit and the conclusion is reached that Egypt is being conciously transformed into a British "protectorate." It is admitted that Lord Cromer's proposals have not yet received the public sanction of the British Government, but is maintained that the Sultan has been definitely dislodged, and that the Egyptian flag is only allowed to float from motives of policy.

Although Lord Cromer's proposals have admittedly not been sanctioned, the Akabah dispute and the Deniahwai incident, both of which are described as having been deliberately provoked, are interpreted as indications of the British Government's probable intentions. If, it is argued, effect is to be given to Lord Cromer's proposols, England "will, of course, require the assent of Germany as well as of other Powers." "In these circumstances," it is added, "it is natural that the Liberal Cabinet should not regard the pronounced differences which now prevail between England and Germany as desirable, and that those who declare that the text of the music to which the latest hymns of peace are being played is to be found in Lord Cromer's report should be oonsidered not altogether wrong." After this the authors and advocates of the recent series of demonstrations of Anglo-German friendship will hardly be surprised to hear that the agitation in favour of the limitations of armaments is regarded merely as another link in the same chain.

Exception is further taken to Lord Cromer's proposal that English, French, and Italian should be recognized as the official languages in the Egyptian law Courts, and in the proceedings of the international board. In view of various German commercial interests, the importance of which is duly estimated in marks and tons, the inclusion of German among the official languages is demanded, and it is urged that this demand should be pressed "in any circumstances." For the present, however, the German Government is advised to wait and see whether Lord Cromer's proposals are sanctioned and "what equivalents the British Goverrment proposes to offer Germany for the renanciation of her treaty rights." What sort of "equivalents" Germany would demand seems clear from the following sentences :— ' I this connexion, moreover, the question will have to be considered whether this occasion, upon whch we are expected to bestow fresh favours upon England, would not be a good opportunity for claiming her friendly compliance with regard to the Persian Gulf terminas of the Baghdad Railway.

For England to persist in her policy of transforming the Persian Gulf into a mare clausum Britannicum would be to throw down the gauntlet (die Macht/rage au/zuuerfen), and her persistence would compel us to meet British Cabinet with the same measure. If the intentions of the present British Cabinet with regard to Germany are really pacific and friendly, the settlement of questions of this kind between the two nations must be effected upon a footing of confiding reciprocity."
Concerning the Pan Islamic movement. Ihe genasis of which is ascribed to British policy, the article observes : —

"If England and France conclude agreements with regard to the future of Mussulman countries, without in any way consulting the inhabitants of these countries, a universal outbreak of discontent throughout the whole of Islam would not be at all unnatural. As a matter of fact, both Powers have reason to be gratefal to Germany for laying stress upon the sovereignty of the Sultan of Morocco and for proposing an international conference in conjunction with the Sultan, since by this means Germany effectually precluded the outbreak of Mahomedan fanaticism, or at any rate robbed it of some very serious pretexts for its manifestation. If the British Government should adopt Lord Cromer's proposals without any alteration, the question might arise whether a similar procedure would not be desirable in the case of Egypt."

div.head: THE LATE MOHAMED PASHA CHERIF.
ARRIVAL OF BODY.
div.p: The Messageries Mari times S.S. Congo, which arrived at Alexandria this morning from Marseilles, had on board the mortal remains of the late Mohamed Pasha Cherif, accompanied by the widow, Moharrem Pasha Chahin, and Mme. Moharrem Pasha Chahin, sister of the deceased. On the arrival of the steamer, a number of notables, including Aly Bey Chahin, master of ceremonies to H.H. the Khedive, and Abdal Rahim Bey Sabry, wekil of the late Pasha's daira, went on board.

The coffin was afterwards landed and placed in position on the quay, wbenaoe it will be removed at 3.30 p.m. to the Mixed Tribunals, where the faneral procession will form up preparatory to proceeding to Moharrem B9y terminus. Here a special train will leave for Cairo with the body of the deoeased at 5.15 p.m.
The funeral will take place in Cairo to-mor-row afternoon at 4.30. from the deoeased's palace in the Sharia El Dawawin ; the interment being performed at El Imam El Shafei.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, according to a native contemporary, will stay three weeks at Stambonl on his reuarn journey to Egypt.

div.head: NEW MINISTRY FOR EGYPT.
div.p: It is possible that the Wakfs Administration may shortly be transformed into a Ministry, in accordance with the opinion of Lord Cromer, published in his last report. The new arrangement is expected to be carried into effect after his lordship's return from Europe.

div.head: A STRANGE LAWSUIT.
div.p: The Civil Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Tribunal will shortly have to pronounce judg-ment in an amusing case.

Some time ago a native barrister gave a commission to a Greek artist to paint his por-trait in oils. It was a three quarter face portrait, and when the work was finished the native barrister was delighted with it and invited all his friends to come and see the masterpiece. They did FO, and to the advocate's disgust, instead of praising the work, maintained a polite hat omioous silence as they gazed at the pioture, and finally one of them asked if he had already paid for it. The barrister replied in th%' negative, and was at once congratulated by his friends, who remarked that the work was a fraud as the painter had only depicted him with one ear.

The advocate recognised that this criticism was only too true and he rushed round to the artist's studio in a state of great indignation, and declared that in view of the just oriticism of his friends he would never pay for the portrait. The artist thought that the man of law was jesting, but when he discovered that the barrister was quite setioi s, he was at pains to explain to him that in a three-quarter face portrait it was only possible for the person so depicted to have one ear visible.
The barrister, however, deolined to regard the argument as valid, and persists in refusing to pay, so the artist has been compelled to bring an action.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Trojan Priuce, with passengers and general cargo, sailed from London on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria on or about the 2nd proxo.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
THE STATE BANK PROPOSAL.
div.p: The Egyptian Government has sent a con-fidential ciroular to all the members of the board of directors of the National Bank of Egypt containirg the conditions which the Government is disposed to accept in the case of the Bank becoming a State banking institution.These conditions are extremely favourable, and there is no doubt but that at the next meeting of the board of directors they will be accepted as they in no way hinder the bank's present system of conducting its business. Moreover, the conditions permit of the bank's making nee of its reserve fond, as it will be replaced by Government Stook, of which a considerable part at least will be placed at the disposal of the bank's reserve 'withoat any interest having to be paid.

div.head: NOTES FROM CONSTANTINOPLE.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: M. N. Christoff, a well known Bulgarian merchant of Amsterdam, is said to have the intention of going to Cairo in order to open a commercial establishment and a Bulgarian commercial museum.

Mgr. Neotarius, Metropolitan of Aleppo, has applied to the Grand Vizier and the Minister of Justice, on behalf of Mgr. Photius, Patriarch of Alexandria, for permission to reconstruct the Orthodox Chnrch of Benghazi.

As soon as the list of candidates for the Catholic Armenian Episcopate of Alexandria reaches the Patriarchate of Sakyz Agatch here, the Holy Synod of the Patriarchate will meet in order to elect the Bishop. As is know, the bishoprio is vacant owing to the election of Mgr. Sabaghian to the Patriarchal Throne of Constantinople.
Some delegates who have come to Constantinople propose to proceed to Alexandria to try and obtain from the Khedivial Mail Line a reduction in freights for Servian exports to Egypt.

div.head: EGYPTIANS IN TURKEY.
div.p: The arrest ff Mahmoud Bey Arif at Stamboul has afforded high Egyptian circles another opportunity to raise the question of a Kapou Kethadasri for Egyptians at Constantinople. A Kapou Kethudassi is a Political Agent accredited to the Sublime Porte, but the appointment has long been deferred owing to the desire of the Khedive to nominate to it an Egyptian belonging to the Maieh Sanieh. To this the sozerain Government objects.

It is to be hoped that daring his stay in Stamboul the Khedive may avail himself of the occasion to approach the Turkish authorities on this subject, which has remained in this undecided state for several years. The Egyptians on the Bosphorus are to all intents and purposes a separate colony, and it is to be hoped that their status as such shall be more clearly defined so that regrettable incidents of the kind just alluded to may in future be avoided.

div.head: REINFORCEMENTS FOR YEMEN.
div.p: The reinforcements now en route to the Yemen, to join Marshal Feizi Pasha's army, number 4,530 officers and men. These are being conveyed by the Turkish troopships Bezmir Alem, Tir Mouzkan, and Abdel- Kader, which passed through the Canal on Sunday bound for Hodeidah. The Bezmir Alem has 2.500 of these reinforcements on board, and the Tir Moozkan 1,110.

div.head: THE BERNAY FATALITY.
div.p: The chauffeor who met his death with H.H. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim in the automobile smash at Bernay was a Spaniard, named Azias, who had lived in Egypt for seven or eight years. After having been employed in the workshops of M. Levasseur, Azias entered the service of the Prince a year ago.

div.head: CAIRO STREET NUISANCE.
div.p: A few days ago we published a complaint from a correspondent concerning the blocking of the pavement Opposite the Savoy Hotel extensions by workmen. Instead of observing any improvement in this state of affairs we remark that the inconvenience to the public has been increased by the addition of the workmen who are employed in mending Kasr-el-Nil road. We are of opinion that the police authorities are in no way justified in ignoring fench reasonable complaints made by the public of Cairo, and we trust that measures will be taken to avoid such an unnecessary inconvenience.

div.head: NEW SUDAN LAND COMPANY.
THE LETTI ESTATES.
div.p: A new company is now being formed to take over a grant of 10,000 acres of agricultural land at Letti, in the Province of Dongola, Sudan, subject to an agreement made with the Sudan Government, in which it is specified that the total capital shall be £100,000, of which £85,000 in £1 Ordinary shares is to be working oapital. The whole of this is to be guaranteed before the public issue of shares. The sum of £13,000 in £1 Ordinary shares is to be held in reserve, while £2,000 of oapital is divided into 40,000 deferred shares of Is. each. These will be allotted in repayment of the expenses of obtaining the grant and of forming the company, which have been borne by the Nile Valley Block "E," Limited. A farther sum of £ 10,500 cash is to be allowed out of working capital for preliminary expenses. The terms of the agreement with the Sudan Government allow two years in which to form and obtain its sanotion to a scheme of irrigation and agriculture, after which a lease will be granted for ten year?, during which the freehold can be purchased at 10s. an acre of all land brought under caltivatior. The £74,500 net working oapital available after payment of all preliminary expenses is considered sufficient to bring the whole property under cultivation, local conditions being economical. The net yearly profits are estimated at from £20,000 to £30,000 per annum, which would be sufficient to yield dividends of from 15 to 20 per cent, on the Ordinary share?, the principal orops being dates, oottoD, and cereals.

div.head: COL. McKINSTRY'S FUNERAL.
div.p: With military honours the funeral of the late Col. A. W. MoKinstry, commander of the Duke of York's Military School, Chelsea, took place on Saturday week at Brompton Cemetery, the coffin, which was covered with a Union Jaok, being conveyed from the school on a gun carriage furnished by "Y" Batt. of the Royal Horse Artillery, and accompanied by the band of the Seots Guards, with drums and pipers. In addition to relatives there were present representatives of that regiment, officers of the school, including Major J. S. Dyke (the Adjutant); Lient Colonel Fayrer (Royal Army Medical Corps); General Sir Martin Dillon, Major-General Sir Ronald Lane, Major General Battcrsby, Colonel Scott, and other officers and non commissioned officers of the 2nd Batt. Leicestershire R'giment, General Mylne, and Colonel Staopole. A detachment of the boys from the sohool, who are now in camp at Hythe, also attended, and the Rev. G. H. Andrews, the chaplain, officiated. The procession was followed to the grave by many spectators.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Holy Synod of the Ecumenical Patriarchate has decided to send a patriarchal and synodal letter to the Patriarch of Alexandria and Jerusalem relative t» the ex-Me ropolitan of the Sea of Antioch, with a to view the reinstatement. The letter invites the Patriarchs to come to Constantinople.
It is probable that Yesrin Bey MuZapba, the Moudir of Keneh, who was injnred in the reoent motor-car accident in Cairo, will offer his resignation.
Sheikh Monssa Ressab, cadi of the province of Dakahlieh, has beeu appointed judge of Abe Grand Mehkemeh of Cairo.
Major C. S. Spong,D.S.O., principal medical officer to the State Railway Administration, has gone to England on two months' leave.
The body of the late Mr. Xenophon Conatantinides arrived at Alexandria this morning fiom Marseilles for interment at Alexandria.

The following will has been proved :— Mrs Helene Edith Mond, of 27, Berkeley-square, S.W., died at Luxor, Egypt, intestate, wife of Mr. Robert Lodwig Mond, of Winningtoc Hall, Northwich,Cheshire,and ot 27, fierkeley-equare, £18,118.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsibl for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit —within certain necessary limits— free discussion.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN. GAZETTE."

Dear Sir,—As one who admires the cleverness but loves not the methods of Mastapha Pasha Kamel, might I be allowed to sfcnd you my impression ot this notorious agitator's* latest escapade. We now hear of him dally living "en prince" at the Carltori Hotel and making wondrous speeches before admiring Little Englanders, to whom In has to-fly, finding that elsewhere his pseudo^patriotio effusions meet with no sympathy. Lit ns remark "en passant" that the Pasha's Well-knowirlaok of the virtue of generosity does not seem to be in evidence at present for he now stints himself in no way in the cause Of "patriotism," for we coaid not suppose that the ohargss of bribery brought by Mr. Findlay upon the local Press could really have been trne, and so an explanation found for the Pasha's prodigality. His present tactics bear a striking resemblance to those of Mark Anthony as depicted by the immortal Shakeipearp. Having, by inflammatory articles in his paper, excited the people to the verge of fanatioism, and to the expectation of a H>ly War by order of the Saltan, he suddenly preaches -calm ! 0! be calm , yj people! He now tells ns. that there is no more dooile race in the world than the Egyptians, and that the charge of fanaticism is absurd. Q rite so, mou oher Pasha, no more dooile race did yon not excite and inflame them with seditions articles ! Finally his Excellency tells his deting audience, which love? to slander its fellow coantrymen abroad, that the mass of the people ooald never have been affeotei by the newspapers owing to their inability to read ' Tho Pasha mast know as well as we do that those that can read, read to those who cannot, and all that they hear is taken as gospel truth; this can be seen any day in the country by those who keep their eyes open.—I am, etc.,
ANTI-PSEUDO PATRIOT.
Medinet-el Fayoum, August 19.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA-RAMLEH RAILWAY.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, — May I through the medium of your valuable newspaper draw the attention of those concerned to an irregularity, of which they are unaware, in the servioe of the tramway beyond San Stefano. On Saturday night I ha 1 to wait 32 minutes before a tram pat in an appearance, and this is by no means an isolated instance of snch delays. Also, in view of the large number of people staying at the Hotel Beau Rivage, it would be much more convenient were the balte closer to the hotel than it is. I am sure that if the directors were aware of this state of things, which is doe to the negleot on the part of their employes, they woald remedy this at once one defect in their excellent service.—I am etc.

div.head: LE PORT D'ALEXANDRIE
CANAL MARITIME
div.p: Nous avons parlé en son temps du projet de l'Administration des Ports et Phares au sujet de la création d'un Canal maritime partant du Jardin Nouzha et traversant le jardin du Gabbari. Les auteurs de ce projet avaient pour but de débarrasser le écluses de Minèted Passai de l'encombrement des barques et de mettre un terme à l'envasement du port in térieur par l'apport des eaux boueuses du Mali- inoudieh. Entre autres avantages, le canal projeté devait permettre aux barques 1 accès direct'dans le port et prévenir pour celui-ci tout danger de contamination.

M. Dietrich Bey, chargé récemment par la Délégation d'émetre son avis sur le projet en question, estime d'abord que la somme de LE. 170,000, fixée par l'ingénieur des Ports et Phares pour l'ensemble dJs travaux, ne peut être qu'approximative. Pour donner un chiffre exact, il faudrait posséder un devis complet et connaître parfaitement la nature du terrain dans le lac Mariout. En outre, il n'a été tenu aucun compte dans le projet des travaux accessoires et imprévus qui accompagnent toujours ces grandes éntrepiises ; en tous cas, les sommes prévues pour cet objet sont cer-tainement insuffisantes. Ainsi la zone maré-cageuse bordant le voie ferrée au sud peut offrir un énorme surcroît de dépenses pour la consolidation des digues du canal, si le sol, qui est de nature vaseuse dans cette localité, vient à s'affaisser sous l'action combinée du poids des terres et des eaux d'infiltration de la mer, ren fermées dans un canal de 60 m. de large dont le plan d'eau sera de 3 mètres plus élevé que le niveau du Mariout.

Pour empêcherla dite infiltration, M. Dietrich trouve préférable d'employer les pierres provenant du creusement du canal dans le jardin du Gabbari pour protéger d'un perré en maçonnerie les talus du côté du canal, au lieu de les employer comme noyau à l'intérieur des digues. Il conseille de plus la construction de plusieurs siphons en maçonnerie permettant aux eaux des masrafs de s'écouler dans le lac Maréotis, pour éviter la formation de marais entre la ligne du chemin de fer et le canal projeté.

Revenant ensuite au devis estimatif des dépenses, il trouve insuffisante la somme de LE. 2800 pour le rehaussement de 4 mètres de la voie ferrée, ainsi que celles de L.E. 12.000 et 8000 pour la construction de l'écluse de 100 mètres en amont du jardin Nouzha et l'achat de terrains dans cette localité ou ailleurs.
Voici maintenant l'opinion de M. Dietrich Bey sur l'opportunité du nouveau canal mari time : —

On sait que l'encombrement des quais pro-vient de l'agglomération des chounahs en certains points, du manque d'espace ou des voies j d'accès commodes et enfin du peu de largeur ,des routes longeant le canal ou y abootiMant. ) affaire», quelques tranHMtion» en Nungov.eh l^es quais sont aussi trop hauts sur une grandi» partie de leur parcours pour le déchargement du coton. Enfin le commerce du bois contribue pour une large part and cet encombrement.

Lorsque les dépôts de bois seront transférés au Gabbari, comme c'est décidé en principe, le canal Mahmoudieh pourra suffire longtemps encore aux nécessités du trafic, moyennant les améliorations suivantes : 1. prolongement des quais jusqu'à la rue Ragheb Pacha ; 2. élargis- '• sement du canal entre le pont Ibrahim et Forn- el-Guéraya. Ce dernier travail donnera lieu à de coûteuses expropriations ; aussi la largeur du canal dans cette partie sera-trelle limitée au strict nécessaire, soit 40 mètres, tandis qu'en amont elle aura 50 mètres. De chaque côté du ( canal proprement dit, il sera réservé 10 mètres de terrain pour un quai en maçonnerie, desti ' tiné à l'entrepôt des marchandises en départ ou en arrivée, et 15 mètres pour la route. Entre le pont Daira Sanieh et l'Usine Electrique des 1 Tramways où les quais sont trop élevés, il fau 1 dra les abaisser ; mais pour cela il faudra pro-céder à des expropriations ; en attendant, on pourrait commencer par les parties Gù le canal est suffisament large pour construire en dessous des quais et routes existantes un nouveau quai de H) mètres pour y déposer les marchandises débarquées avant leur entrée en chounah.

div.head:
French In Egypt
PRAISE OF BRITISH ADMINISTRATION

div.p: The "Journal" published a letter signed by a group of Frenchmen, established in Egypt, who express the hope that England will continue to for the progress of Egypt. They declare that the recent British precautions were folly justifiable. (Reuter)

div.head:
VALPARAISO EARTHQUAKE.
END OF PANIC.
END OF PANIC.

div.p: According to the latest accoonts direct from Santiago, about 50 persons have been killed at Valparaiso and the same number at Santiago. It seems that many poblio buildings, including tho>e of the Ministry of the Interior and the Palace of Congress at Santiago, have been damaged. (Reuter)

The estimates of the mortality at Valparaiso continue to vary immensely, but it is believed to bo relatively small in comparison to the enormous damage done. The hotels are standing, and all the oooupants are safe. The inhabitants are huddled on the hills, a the parks, and on the beach. The wateraains are burst, and water and food are lacking. / (ftawfsr)
The panic is over. Airong the dead is the representative of the Havas Agency. The losses are said to exceed a milliard of francs. (//.) SANTIAGO, August 20. The number of dead in the city is 50. (H.)

div.head:
JAPAN AND MANCHURIA.
A BIG LOAN WANTED

div.p: Baron Takahashi, Vice-Governor of the Bank of Japan, is about to proceed to Eugland and America in order to negotiate a loan of 8O,000.000 yen for the purpose of Manohurian enterprise, and also, if possible, to negotiate for a reduction of interest on old loans. (R.)

div.head:
GREAT BRITAIN AND SERVIA
RELATIONS RENEWED.

div.p: Relations between Great Britain and Servia have been renewed. Mr. Whitehead has presented his credentials to King Peter. Cordial speeches were made. (Rdw/ur)
M. Zaimis is to be appointed Governor of the Island of Crete. (Havas)
The Porte has drawn the attention of the Powers to the serious danger attending the anti-Greek movement in Bulgaria. (Reuter)
The polioe have discovered a plot to assassinate M. Failures during his visit to the city. An Italian Anarchist named Cirillo has teen arrested. (Reuter)

Xsa result of the Montagu court-martial, Captain Thomas Adair and Lieutenant Dathan Lave been severely reprimanded and dismissed their ship. Lieutenant Dathan, besides, loses two years seniority. (Reuter)

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
REFORMS IN PERSIA.
div.p: The influence of the mollahs or Mahomedan clergy is peculiarly strong in Persia. They have preserved an ecclesiastical organization unknown in other Moslem countries, and they wield considerable judicial powers. They are the only body capable of standing between the rulers and the people ; and, with all their faults, they have on more than one occasion interposed their influence against misgovernment when carried to intolerable lengths. Naturally also they have of recent years come to stand as the representatives of the nationalfeeling of Persia against foreign, influences. Between them and the Shah the breach has been steadily growing wider. Some time ago the priests at Kcrbelah actually threatened the Shah with excommunication. Last December the leading Mojtehids of Teheran, to express their protest against the misgovernment of the country, practically went on strike by taking eanotuary in a shrine and thus suspending all their judicial work. They were temporarily quieted by promises, which, *gpf course, were not carried out. Bat last month the trouble broke out again, and in a more acute form. Under the influenc3 of events in Rassia tin populace of Teheran began to olamour for some form of representative insti-tutions. Serious street fights took plaoe iu Teheran, and eventually the whole body of Mojtehids left the city, while their adherents, afraid of the vengeance of the Coart faction, took refage in the grounds of the British Legation—an interesting testimony of the confidonce fe't in Persia in our power and our sympathy with reform. ( "Times.")

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
